update.description:
Couple things in particular that need looking at:

I moved “Empty //pose and //frame elements imply identity pose” to the “Terminology” section \(1.3\). It was in the “New semantics” section \(now “Name conflicts and scoping rules…“\), and before that the “Model frame and canonical link” section.

Section 3.1, “Scoping rules for referencing frames by name“, is new and doesn’t have any info on previous versions or reasoning.

There’s a few places that would benefit from linking to other sections in the doc, but it seems like markdown doesn’t allow that? Anyone know?

[http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose\_frame\_semantics\_proposal&cat=pose\_semantics\_docs&branch=pose\_frame\_proposal\_redo](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&branch=pose_frame_proposal_redo)
update.title: revisions for pose frame proposal

content.raw:
That’s right, it’s there to maintain the structure.  If I combine the two statements, maybe it will sound less awkward but still fulfill the template:

“Defining these semantics, which were missing from SDFormat 1.5, minimizes redundancy in poses and offsets and make relationships between physical elements easier to interpret.”

Or something like that.

‌

Or something like that.

content.raw:
there are two ways to make code blocks: indenting and wrapping in `~~~`

if you want to have multiple distinct code blocks, you need to wrap them in `~~~`. If you indent them, they will all merge into a single code block.

I think indenting the `~~~` characters causes them to be included in the code block, so it should be one or the other, not both
content.html:
there are two ways to make code blocks: indenting and wrapping in ~~~

if you want to have multiple distinct code blocks, you need to wrap them in ~~~. If you indent them, they will all merge into a single code block.

I think indenting the ~~~ characters causes them to be included in the code block, so it should be one or the other, not both

content.raw: this seems like part of the template that was used for this PR: "how it differs from existing functionality, and why the change is necessary"
content.html: this seems like part of the template that was used for this PR: "how it differs from existing functionality, and why the change is necessary"

content.raw:
I’m ok with removing this one, it doesn’t add anything. But which other ones do you think are redundant? 

I think section 6, \`Details of `//pose/@relative_to` attribute\` has the same issue with its summary. But the rest seem more a little more explicit to me.
content.html:
I’m ok with removing this one, it doesn’t add anything. But which other ones do you think are redundant?

I think section 6, `Details of //pose/@relative_to attribute` has the same issue with its summary. But the rest seem more a little more explicit to me.

I looked around and I don’t think Markdown can do it out-of-the-box.  It is bad that numbers will have to be manually changed though.

At least right now there’s only one anchor that references a numbered section \(line 77\)

I looked around and I don’t think Markdown can do it out-of-the-box. It is bad that numbers will have to be manually changed though.

content.html: Having “parity” after the attribute / element sounds a bit odd; can the original title be restored, or be restated as “Parity with URDF using //pose/@relative_to?

content.raw:
nit Is there a way that we could somehow have Markdown /  HTML handle this numbering?

Main concern is that this affects the anchors, where they’d get invalidated if a new section gets added in before it. \(Perhaps not a huge deal…\)
content.html:
nit Is there a way that we could somehow have Markdown / HTML handle this numbering?

Main concern is that this affects the anchors, where they’d get invalidated if a new section gets added in before it. (Perhaps not a huge deal…)

content.html: Or perhaps this (and other restated motivations) would be better as introductions to the change sections, rather than summarizing it?

content.raw:
I think we don't explicitly define the user-configuration or default value of the canonical link here, though we discuss it a bit after the short examples.

Perhaps we should add: The name of the canonical link can be specified in the `//model/@canonical_link` attribute. If it is not specified, then the first `//link` element in the model is chosen as the canonical link.
content.html:
I think we don't explicitly define the user-configuration or default value of the canonical link here, though we discuss it a bit after the short examples.

Perhaps we should add: The name of the canonical link can be specified in the //model/@canonical_link attribute. If it is not specified, then the first //link element in the model is chosen as the canonical link.
